Article.Abstract: The three-dimensional structures of the free and antigen-complexed Fabs from the mouse monoclonal anti-hen egg white lysozyme antibody D44.1 have been solved and refined by X-ray crystallographic techniques. The crystals of the free and lysozyme-bound Fabs were grown under identical conditions and their X-ray diffraction data were collected to 2.1 and 2.5 A, respectively. Two molecules of the Fab-lysozyme complex in the asymmetric unit of the crystals show nearly identical conformations and thus confirm the essential structural features of the antigen-antibody interface. Three buried water molecules enhance the surface complementarity at the interface and provide hydrogen bonds to stabilize the complex. Two hydrophobic buried holes are present at the interface which, although large enough to accommodate solvent molecules, are void. The combining site residues of the complexed FabD44.1 exhibit reduced temperature factors compared with those of the free Fab. Furthermore, small perturbations in atomic positions and rearrangements of side-chains at the combining site, and a relative rearrangement of the variable domains of the light (VL) and the heavy (VH) chains, detail a Fab accommodation of the bound lysozyme. The amino acid sequence of the VH domain, as well as the epitope of lysozyme recognized by D44.1 are very close to those previously reported for the monoclonal antibody HyHEL-5. A feature central to the FabD44.1 and FabHyHEL-5 complexes with lysozyme are three salt bridges between VH glutamate residues 35 and 50 and lysozyme arginine residues 45 and 68. The presence of the three salt bridges in the D44.1-lysozyme interface indicates that these bonds are not responsible for the 1000-fold increase in affinity for lysozyme that HyHEL-5 exhibits relative to D44.1.
Article.ArticleTitle: Three-dimensional structures of the free and the antigen-complexed Fab from monoclonal anti-lysozyme antibody D44.1.
Article.Affiliations: Center for Advanced Research in Biotechnology, University of Maryland Biotechnology Institute, Rockville, MD 20850.
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Amino Acid Sequence; Animals; Antibodies, Monoclonal(chemistry); Antigen-Antibody Complex(chemistry); Antigen-Antibody Reactions; Chickens; Crystallization; Egg White; Hybridomas; Hydrogen Bonding; Immunoglobulin Fab Fragments(chemistry); Mice; Molecular Sequence Data; Muramidase(immunology); Protein Conformation; Protein Structure, Secondary; Sequence Alignment; Water(chemistry); X-Ray Diffraction

Epitope.EpitopeName: epitope 1 and 2 on hen egg white lysozyme HEL recognized by D44.1 Fab

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: 1 dose of 100 µg in CFA, followed by 50 µg in PBS i.v. 14 days later

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Generation of the monoclonal antibody was previously described in the reference cited: Harper et al. (1987) Mol Immunol 24: 97-108 [PMID: 2441250]. MAb D44.1 belongs to a group of BALB/c antibodies including HyHEL-5. MAb D44.1 typifies the lower limit of affinities amongst the antibodies of the same group.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The epitope of D44.1 Fab on hen egg white lysozyme (HEL) was determined from the structure of the complex solved by molecular replacement. The structure [PDB:1MLC] contains two complexes Fab-HEL with the same epitope and paratope residues, but differ slightly by number of Fab-HEL contacts, and also slightly different conformation of Fab; therefore two complexes are curated as separate assays.

ThreeDimensionalStructureOfComplex.Comments: Conformations of the complexed and free Fab [PDB: 1MLB] are different. Comparison of HEL molecules in the complex with Fab D44.1 with uncomplexed HEL [PDB: 2lzt, 1hel, 1lma] reveal little changes in main-chain accommodation necessary to form complex. Epitope residue E: D66 and Fab residues B: G99, A:R96, A:S91 involved only in water-mediated contacts, but not in direct contacts. Epitope residue E:R68 and Fab residue B:W33 have stacking interaction.
